tier.item: (1) Ic. ... hvort henni líka strákarnir
... if her.DAT like.3PL boys-the.NOM (10) bátur ­ bát ­ báti ­ (báts) ('boat')
Fa. a.
'... if she likes the boys'

Fa. a.
... if she likes the boys
(2) Fa. ... um henni dámar drongirnar
In Danish, nominative and accusative coalesced early in the 13th century (Karker 2001: 77), and Hrafnbjargarson
... if her.DAT likes.3SG boys-the.ACC
(2004: 44-48) shows that dative singular marking started to disappear around 1200, and that dative plural marking
'... if she likes the boys'

(6) RD. þurufiriþi likaþi can be nominative.
Thorfrid.DAT liked
Falk (1997: 25-43) compares what seems to be oblique subjects in Old Swedish with Icelandic oblique subjects.
'Thorfrid was pleased' (ca. 800, DR EM85;348)
(6) RD. þurufiriþi likaþi can be nominative.
Thorfrid.DAT liked
Falk (1997: 25-43) compares what seems to be oblique subjects in Old Swedish with Icelandic oblique subjects.

RD. þurufiriþi likaþi can be nominative.
Thorfrid.DAT liked

(12) OE. þam wife þa word wel licodon
ical cases. The interesting fact about Faroese is that it seems to be in the process of moving from the -
The.DAT woman.DAT the.PL.NOM words.NOM well liked.3PL DATIVE
'The woman liked the words well' (cobeowul 639.538) stage, as in (19) and (20) to the NOMINATIVE-ACCUSATIVE stage as in (21). According to Barnes

shows person and number agreement with the nominative NP. In corresponding (DAT-NOM) constructions in Ice-
Me.DAT like.3PL those.NOM.PL boats.NOM.PL
landic, the verb only shows agreement with third person nominative elements.
'I like those boats'

ME. þonne soðlice Gode licað ure drohtnunge
then truly God.DAT.SG likes.3SG our living.ACC.PL century Faroese and Old and Middle Danish. Speakers of Faroese born after 1960 do not allow for oblique subjects.

(18) MD. Honum thøkte sek vara i en lysteligen stath

(26) Ic. a. Hún hélt mér hafa líkað gjöfin In the second class (usually called class N verbs), either dative or accusative is the case of the experiencer and
She.NOM believed.3SG me.DAT have.INF liked.SUP present-the.NOM
genitive is the case of the theme:
'She believed I had liked the present'

(33) Ge. Erst dann gefiel dem Intendanten das Ensemble
First then pleased the.DAT manager the.NOM ensemble occurs with a nominative object. In the two last examples (DAT-?), it is ambiguous which case the object is marked
'First then, the ensemble pleased the manager'

In the PPCME2, there are three examples of the same verb (areowe). There are two examples of areowe with an
The.DAT woman.DAT the.PL.NOM words.NOM well liked.3PL
'The woman liked the words well' (cobeowul 639.538) oblique subject, the third example is an imperative. The example in (39) is the only example where both arguments

(41) OE. Ac him ne ofhreow na þæs deofles hryre
I have also argued that Old English and Middle English had dative subjects and nominative objects and that
But him.DAT not pitied never the.GEN devil.GEN fall.NOM
the change from DAT-NOM to NOM-ACC in English followed the same principles as the same change in the

(42) OE. him ofhreow þæt astepede wif
there have been no changes in the semantics from Old English to Modern English. Rather there has been a reanalysis
him.DAT pitied the.ACC deprived.ACC woman.ACC
'he pitied the deprived woman' (cogregdH 9.142) in the case assignment of verbs in DAT-NOM constructions. To begin with, these verbs lost their ability to assign
